title: 106_hr5305
content: The Act may be cited as the "Community Assistance Act of 2000". It includes findings. Congress finds that small communities are concerned about improving environmental quality, uncertain about specific environmental regulations, often excluded from the rulemaking process, underrepresented in EPA regulation reviews, lack technical capacity to understand requirements, face compliance issues with certain environmental laws, and are supported by the Small Town Environmental Planning Task Force. The Small Town Environmental Planning Task Force, established by the Federal Facility Compliance Act of 1992, recommends improving EPA services for small communities. The purpose of this Act is to promote a healthy environment for people in small communities to have a sustainable quality of life. Definitions include terms like Administrator, advisory committee, Agency, and small community. The small community advisory committee is established under section 5. The Administrator will establish a small community advisory committee composed of representatives from small communities, governmental agencies, and public interest groups. The committee's duties include improving the Agency's relationship with small communities, involving them in developing environmental regulations, and providing reports to Congress. The Administrator will establish a small community advisory committee to improve the Agency's relationship with small communities, involve them in developing environmental regulations, and provide reports to Congress. The committee will also provide periodic reports to Congress on the Agency's success in meeting the needs of small communities and offer assistance as deemed appropriate by the Administrator. The Administrator will develop a plan to increase small communities' involvement in regulatory review processes and implement regional outreach efforts to small communities. Each regional office of the Agency will establish a Small Town Ombudsman Office to advocate for and address concerns of small communities. The Administrator will provide necessary resources for these offices to function efficiently. Each regional Small Town Ombudsman Office will have an ongoing consultation process with small communities to involve them in environmental regulations and provide assistance as needed. SEC. 8. SURVEY OF SMALL COMMUNITIES. The Small Town Ombudsman Office conducts a survey every 5 years to collect information on sources used for environmental regulations, facilities impacting environmental quality, financial instruments for environmental services, contacts for compliance information, and specific regulation topics. The purpose is to provide data for regulatory planning and outreach. The Small Town Ombudsman Office conducts a survey every 5 years to collect information on sources used for environmental regulations, facilities impacting environmental quality, financial instruments for environmental services, contacts for compliance information, and specific regulation topics. The survey includes specific topic areas of regulation relevant to small communities, innovative compliance examples, and any other topics deemed appropriate by the Administrator. SEC. 9. GUIDE FOR SMALL COMMUNITIES. The Administrator will create and distribute a guide to Federal environmental requirements for small communities within 6 months of this Act. The guide will outline all mandated environmental requirements and provide contacts for Federal, regional, and State agencies. It will be updated annually to reflect any changes. SEC. 10. FEEDBACK PLAN. SEC. 10. FEEDBACK PLAN. The Administrator will develop a plan to gather feedback from small communities on the Agency's effectiveness in involving them in regulatory development and providing assistance. SEC. 11. NO IMPOSITION OF COSTS ON SMALL COMMUNITIES. Small communities will not be charged for any costs related to this Act. SEC. 12. REPORT. Within 2 years of enactment, the Administrator will submit a report to Congress detailing the regulatory review and feedback plans, and other activities. SEC. 13. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 13. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $5,000,000 authorized for this Act.
